review.title: On Simulated Annealing Dedicated to Maximin Latin Hypercube Designs
review.abstract: The goal of our research was to enhance local search heuristics used to construct Latin Hypercube Designs. First, we introduce the \textit{1D-move} perturbation to improve the space exploration performed by these algorithms. Second, we propose a new evaluation function $\psi_{p,\sigma}$ specifically targeting the Maximin criterion.

metadata.title: On Simulated Annealing Dedicated to Maximin Latin Hypercube Designs

sections.text: In order to construct Latin hypercube designs, we first introduce 1D tensile disturbance to improve the space exploration performed by these algorithms. Secondly, we propose a new evaluation function specifically aimed at the maximin criterion. Exhaustive experiments with simulated annealing, which we used as a typical well-functioning local search heuristics, confirm that our goal has been achieved, as the result we have achieved exceeds the best values recorded in the literature. Furthermore, the p function seems promising for a wide range of optimization problems due to the maximin criterion.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The study of complex systems usually requires considerable computing time. To accelerate the calculations, the system can be replaced by a faster approximation model. To create this model, a series of results is required for different parameter values. The set of parameter values has an impact on the accuracy of the approximation model. Different sampling methods for this set of parameters were proposed in [4]. Taking into account the number of inputs of the system and n the number of possible values by an input variable xk, the choice of n sample vectors can be represented by points on a hypercube of size and dimension k. Among the proposed designs, we focus on the Maximin Latin hypercube design (LHD). The LHD implements the Latin constraint: each coordinate in [1; n |] must appear only once in each dimension. In other words, the coordinates of any node differ in all dimensions.

sections.heading: 2 Typical approach to solve Maximin LHD with Simulated Annealing
sections.text: SA is a metaheuristics most commonly used for discrete search spaces inspired by a metallurgical process. It consists in visiting the search space with a disturbance of the configurations and deciding whether the mutated configuration should be selected. Therefore, it alternates phases of heating and slow cooling to influence this choice: As in physics, we give the configuration the opportunity to find the lowest energy. It has been proven that SA approaches the global minimum probability of the metropolis [1]. Several ingredients are mandatory for SA [3]: a disturbance (a mutation), an evaluation function Hpot (also referred to as potential energy) and a temperature decrease T (k), where k is the iteration number. The probability of acceptance depends on T (k) and the gap of potential energy between the new and the old configuration.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this article, we present new techniques for treating the Maximin LHD construction, the first being the 1D Move mutation specifically tailored to the LHD structure, which is very efficient for local search for LHDs because it allows you to follow a step-by-step path on the cost surface without jumping over possible minimums, and the second tool, the p evaluation function, focuses directly on maximin optimization. As numerous problems, including Maximin designs, include this criterion, we emphasize that this function can be used for many other applications. In the Maximin LHD context, the p function attempts to find solutions by narrowing a number of possible distances. SA, with 1D-Move and p, σ, provided better results than those considered "the most well-known" in most cases without any special coordination.
